text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with ham and red-eye gravy

or not make a gravy with leftover coffee

thick pieces and then any of the scraps
and he the fat you trimmed off I want

we're going to use that to make the base
of the red-eye gravy
I'm going to put a saute pan on medium

those scraps until they're well browned
and they give up most of their fat all
right and you got to be careful because
ham is cured with salt and sugar so
you'll see there starts to caramelize
starts getting sticky and when you're
little meat pieces start sticking to
your wooden spoon that's a good sign
that you're done so when it looks like
that I'm going to turn off the heat I'm
going to remove those pieces of ham but
I'm going to leave all that fat behind
all right turn the heat back on medium
and then we're going to go ahead and
Brown our ham slices alright don't
forget back in the day people didn't try
to avoid fat they tried to figure out
how to get more of it in the diet so
this was a way to turn that excess fat
into a palatable gravy that you could
serve over your meat over your grits
over your rise over your bland starchy
side dishes to get some more energy to
keep you going and while it's browning
if you want to put a little more pepper

so once that's brown well on both sides
we're going to remove it from the pan
all right you're just going to reserve

put in just a pinch of flour now
traditionally this doesn't have flour in
it it's just coffee and fat but I do
like to put a couple pinches in just to
give it a little bit of body a little
bit of binding and it's going to make
what we call a temporary emulsification
we're going to cook that flour for about
two minutes at that point I want you to
turn the heat back up to medium-high and
then we're going to dump in old coffee
that's right just left
black coffee bitter harsh but something
happens to it when it hits that slightly

the answer to that question
all right so whisk in your coffee that
flour is just going to thicken it up
ever so slightly it's going to emulsify
with that pork fat and you're going to
have what sort of looks like a gravy now
you're going to have to taste it
depending on how salty your ham was you
may have to season this maybe some
pepper maybe some cayenne you know the

just long enough to warm it and that is
done all right doesn't look that bad
right but like I said it's only a
temporary emulsion if you let that sit
there for like a half-hour
eventually the fat and the coffee will
separate because there's just not enough
flour in there to really hold everything
together and you really don't want a lot
of flour in this it's not supposed to be

and how does it taste very interesting
